item.description:
This meetup's topic is "Managing Database State Changes" by Jacob Nikom.

Just like the software applications that use them, databases evolve over time to reflect
the changes in the business requirements. However, while contemporary software
applications have well developed tools and methodology to handle those changes
(every developer uses Subversion, CVS, SourceSafe, ClearCase or other configuration
management system or CMS), for databases those methods and tools are not standardized
in such a degree.

Modern CMS manages source code changes based on file names by storing the
differences (so called deltas) between subsequent changes in the code for each source
file. Many database change management (DCM) tools work differently. They go directly
to schema and show the differences in data for particular tables. In case of large tables it
is difficult to observe and understand those differences. For example, just looking at the
data in a server tables it is not always obvious whether that server has all necessary data
to run particular application successfully.

Therefore, instead of comparing the data directly, it could be beneficial to compare
references to those data. Those references are the names of the SQL scripts which were
used to create and fill out the database. If there is a list of such files and if all the database
changes happened only as a result of application of those SQL scripts, the state of the
database uniquely identified by the scripts names and their order.

Based on those ideas we created a program - CatalogVersion - which implements the
DCM functionality by tracking the names of the applied SQL scripts used to create or
upgrade our servers. It was successfully used by all our software developers and QA
testers for creating new servers, upgrading the existing ones to particular version. It also
allows using traditional CSM tools for managing SQL scripts.

This talk discusses the DCM principles and their implementation by CatalogVersion
program. It also shares author experience and tips for other DBAs when they perform this
type of work.
